description:
Malania oleifera is a species of flowering plant that belongs to the family Malaniaceae. It is an evergreen tree native to the southern region of China, primarily found in the provinces of Guangxi and Yunnan.

The tree can grow up to 20 meters in height and has a straight, cylindrical trunk with a grayish-brown bark. The leaves are simple, alternate, and oblong-lanceolate in shape, measuring around 10-15 cm in length and 3-5 cm in width. The leaves are dark green in color and have a leathery texture.

Malania oleifera produces small, yellowish-white flowers that are arranged in terminal panicles. The flowers are bisexual and have four sepals and four petals. The fruit of the plant is a drupe, which is oval-shaped and measures around 3-4 cm in length. The fruit contains a single seed that is rich in oil, which is the primary reason for the plant's cultivation.

The oil extracted from the seeds of Malania oleifera is highly valued for its nutritional and industrial applications. It is rich in oleic acid and has a unique flavor and aroma. The oil is commonly used in cooking, as well as in the production of cosmetics and lubricants.

Malania oleifera is considered a threatened species due to habitat loss and overharvesting. Conservation efforts are underway to protect and cultivate this valuable plant species.
